questionListItems.title: What is a professional pilot licence?

answer.body:
There are three types of professional pilot licences viz. Commercial Pilot Licence (CPL), Multi-crew Pilot Licence (MPL) and Airline Transport Pilot Licence (ATPL). These are meant for pilots who would like to pursue commercial flying as a career. The privileges of each licence are listed below:


Privileges

Commercial Pilot Licence (CPL)

Multi-crew Pilot Licence (MPL)

Airline Transport Pilot Licence (ATPL)

Entitled to fly as
Pilot-In-Command (PIC)
(Single Pilot Operation)

Yes

No

Yes

For those who have upgraded to an ATPL from an MPL, PIC privileges are not given for Groups A & B aircraft*

Entitled to fly as
Co-pilot
(Multi-crew Operation)

Yes

Provided the licence holder has completed the ATPL examinations

Yes

Yes

Entitled to fly as
Pilot-In-Command (PIC)
(Multi-crew Operation)

No

No

Yes

Entitled to conduct instrument flying

No

Instrument flying privileges are not included in the licence privileges. To conduct instrument flying, an Instrument Rating has to be obtained separately.

Yes

Yes

*Group A aircraft: Single-engine aircraft not exceeding 5,700 kg in maximum total mass
Group B aircraft: Multi-engine aircraft not exceeding 5,700 kg in maximum total mass.

questionListItems.title: How do I convert my foreign Private Pilot License (PPL) to a Singapore PPL?

answer.body:
You will need to submit the application form and supporting documents online in CAPELS.

In order to convert your foreign PPL, you must meet the following requirements:


  • Hold a valid foreign PPL issued by an ICAO Contracting State. The PPL must remain valid throughout the conversion process.

  • Be certified to at least an "Operational Level" (Level 4) on the ICAO Language Proficiency Rating Scale.

  • Pass the following examinations and tests:

    • Class 2 Medical Assessment or Class 1 Medical Assessment if a PPL with Instrument Rating (IR) is sought;

    • PPL Air Law and Operational Procedures examination;

    • PPL Human Performance examination; and

    • PPL flight test

All of the above requirements have to be completed within a 6-month period.
The detailed requirements can be found in the Singapore Air Safety Publication Part 1.

questionListItems.title: How do I renew my Certificate of Experience (C of E)?

answer.body:
To renew your Certificate of Experience, you are required to meet the following conditions:

  • Fly a minimum of 5 hours, of which 2 hours must be under the instruction of a Flying Instructor

  • The flight(s) must be on a Singapore-registered aircraft and completed within the 12 months preceding the date of expiry of a Certificate of Experience or Certificate of Test

Renew your Certificate of Experience for your PPL via CAPELS. To complete your application, you will be required to upload the following information:

  • Certified logbook entries

  • Copy of your Certificate of Experience or Certificate of Test

If your Certificate of Experience has lapsed, you are required to pass the PPL flight test for renewal.

questionListItems.title: How do I renew my Private Pilot License (PPL)?

answer.body:
You can renew your PPL online through CAPELS.

Do note that you are required to hold a valid Class 2 Medical Assessment issued by the Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB).

questionListItems.title: How do I lift the navigation restriction in my Restricted Private Pilot License (PPL)?

answer.body: You may submit an application for a PPL (without navigation restrictions), if you have completed at least 5 hours of solo flying on cross-country flights. The 5 hours of solo flying should include a flight not less than 150 nautical miles, during which the holder has to make two intermediate stops within a day. One of the two stops made must be at least 50 nautical miles away from the aerodrome of departure.

questionListItems.title: What is a Restricted Private Pilot License (PPL)?

answer.body: A Restricted PPL is issued by CAAS to individuals who are unable to meet the navigation requirements of the PPL. The holder of such a licence is permitted to fly within Singapore only.

questionListItems.title: What is the validity period of the Private Pilot License (PPL)?

answer.body:
The maximum validity of the PPL corresponds with the applicant's age, as follows:


  • <40 years old - valid for 60 months

  • =40 years old but <50 years old - valid for 24 months

  • =50 years old but <60 years old - valid for 12 months

  • =60 years old - valid for 6 months

questionListItems.title: What are the different Aircraft Ratings that Private Pilot License (PPL) holders can obtain?

answer.body:
Aircraft ratings are qualifications that allow PPL holders to fly different types of aircraft. As a PPL holder, you may act as a Pilot-in-Command for the following aircraft groups:


  • Group A: Single-engine aircraft not exceeding 5,700 kg in maximum total mass

  • Group B: Multi-engine aircraft not exceeding 5,700 kg in maximum total mass

  • Group C: A specific type of aircraft with a maximum total mass that exceeds 5,700 kg

The specific aircraft rating (A, B or C) you hold will be specified on the PPL.

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements for a Private Pilot License (PPL)?

answer.body:
In order to obtain a PPL, you would need to meet the following requirements:

  • Be at least 17 years old

  • Pass the Class 2 Medical Assessment with the Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB) or pass the Class 1 Medical assessment if you are applying for a PPL with Instrument Rating (IR)

  • Pass the PPL examinations. You may apply for the examinations at the CAAS Examination Portal.

  • Pass the PPL flight test. You may apply for the flight test on CAPELS.

  • Meet the flying experience requirements stipulated in the Singapore Air Safety Publication (SASP) Part 1.

questionListItems.title: What is a Private Pilot Licence (PPL)?

answer.body:
The PPL allows pilots to fly a Singapore-registered aircraft, for leisure.

The PPL is a licence that allows pilots to fly any Singapore-registered aircraft, for leisure purposes. With the PPL, pilots are permitted to fly out of Singapore.

questionListItems.title: How do I renew my Student Pilot License (SPL)?

answer.body:
You can renew your SPL online through CAPELS.

Do note that you are required to hold a valid Class 2 Medical Assessment issued by the Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB) in order to renew your SPL.

questionListItems.title: What is the validity period of the Student Pilot License (SPL)?

answer.body:
The maximum validity of the SPL corresponds with the applicant's age, as follows:

  • <40 years old - valid for 60 months

  • =40 years old but <50 years old - valid for 24 months

  • =50 years old but <60 years old - valid for 12 months

  • =60 years old - valid for 6 months

The validity of the SPL starts from the date of issue or renewal of the applicant's Class 2 Medical Assessment, whichever is earlier.

The maximum age for holding an SPL is 65 years old.

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements for a Student Pilot License (SPL)

answer.body: You have to be at least 16 years old (but below 65 years old) and have passed the Class 2 Medical Assessment with the Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB). Once you have passed the medical assessment, submit the online application for SPL through CAPELS.

questionListItems.title: What is a Student Pilot Licence (SPL)?

answer.body: The SPL allows aspiring pilots to fly as the sole occupant in a Singapore-registered aircraft during the course of training through a CAAS approved Flying Training Organisation or a flying club, to eventually obtain a pilot licence such as the Private Pilot Licence or Commercial Pilot Licence.

questionListItems.title: Where are the flight crew or aircraft maintenance licensing examinations conducted?

answer.body:
These examinations are conducted at the CAAS Examination Centre in Changi Airport Terminal 2. The address is:

60 Airport Boulevard, Changi Airport Terminal 2,
Unit #B1/63-64
Singapore 819643
